Text: The complicated web of relationships that have arisen from the Lhao Tribe's past remained tangled, \n while Banga Settlement was returning to the city of Jirga Para Lhao to get much needed supplies.

Great job out there! 
 Feels good to teach Vogo 
 he can't screw around 
 with us.

You know, they call him 
 the "Fallen Sun" behind 
 his back. He's nothing 
 like his father...

You're just like all 
 the others who think 
 some low-born is a 
 better Sun than me.
Feeling smug, \n aren't you?

She seemed serious too. 
 Was putting everything 
 she had into taking it 
 over.

It's a special time 
 for the Lhao Tribe.

 ceremony to perform.

 the Forbidden Land! You 
 must've brought back a

 just wanted to pay the 
 settlement back for 
 taking me in.
Don't give me that \n look! I know you think \n I'm beneath you.
Brother, do you remember the first time we met? \n I was a nobody, frightened of my own shadow.

It's the talk of all the 
 miners - the rumour is

 itself!

We appreciate everything \n you and your father \n have done for us.
It was the Sun Family \n that rescued you and \n your mum.
We're heading \n to port! \n Cast off!
So remember \n your place.

But we both endured it. You said the lion's symbol 
 would give us courage. And since then, I've always 
 believed you when you said the lion made us true 
 brothers. So please, for me, show courage now.
You gave me a sign that I was your brother. I can still feel its hot \n press on my skin. When he found out, your father wanted to kill us.
Who do you think \n got you to where \n you are today?
You seem to have nothing \n but free moments, why \n don't you help?
Vogo, you will respect our \n agreement. You promised to \n give us back fair trading terms.
Then why!? \n Why won't you be on \n my side, just once!?

Heck, even if Fi isn't 
 related by blood, he's a 
 better Sun than that 
 Vogo.

If I was younger, I 
 could help with the 
 preparations, but as it 
 is with this bad hip...

I think Vogo knows it, 
 that's why he's always 
 acting like he has 
 something to prove.
The whip that Vogo had attempted to use on the Banga Settlement \n was ironically stayed by the hand of Fi. If Fi hadn't done what \n he had, Banga Settlement would've continued to suffer under it.
I see... And now I \n get why they don't \n resemble each other.
Cecie, what are you \n doing out here?
Oh, ah, Lisa's doing \n something important \n inside...
Important?
Equip a talisman.
Equipped a talisman.
I give you praise, \n proud ancestor spirits \n of the Lhao Tribe.
May you somehow \n be at peace...
You're giving me \n strange looks.

This ritual is a part 
 of who we are. The 
 Cargo our ancestors 
 need to rest is gone.
Cargo...?
My people, the Lhao Tribe, were once the \n proud rulers of the sacred city of Jirga Para Lhao. \n Until the invaders came...
The invaders tricked my ancestors and stole the Cargo, our heritage. They \n created the Council and started a war that cost my people many lives.
Our sacred city was stolen from us, and since then, we've become \n a wandering people. One day, the descendants of the Lhao Tribe \n will take back what's ours and restore us to our former glory.

Some children get 
 nursery rhymes, I got 
 that from my elders 
 every night.

But it's just a fairy tale. 
 And these silly rituals are 
 all that's left to us while we 
 struggle to survive.
L-Look!
Nice, so the winner of this \n bet gets it all, and the \n loser loses everything!
If Banga wins, you'll revise \n the terms of the contract to \n be more favourable to us.
Which seems reasonable \n given how unfair the \n terms have been.

You know, I wasn't 
 expecting a businessman 
 like you to make such an 
 interesting wager!
Why am I talking to \n you!? Get Lisa out \n here this instant!
We heard \n everything.
Ack!
If Banga loses, our contract \n commitment gets tripled! \n Right, Moustache?
Yeah, I'm not in this \n business for my health.
Vogo, what's \n behind all this?
What are you going to do \n if we refuse the wager?
I heard you entered the \n Forbidden Land... I know where \n you got that last shipment.
How do you think the Council \n will react once they hear about \n that secret treasure trove?
L-Lisa, \n I'm sorry.
Now I get it. You're just trying \n to justify putting a bigger squeeze \n on us. Alright, what's the bet?

The deal isn't all bad 
 for you, this could be 
 your chance to turn 
 things around.
We'll use the machines \n I'm delivering to the \n Garrison Forces to play.

Fine. The person who \n knocks down 10 targets \n first wins.
They're rigged to pop up \n and drop automatically.

 them down when they're 
 up to get credit for the

 best of three? Don't 
 want the fun to end too 
 quickly.

Representing Sun \n Shipping will be my \n brother Fi.

 a long line of Lhao 
 warriors.
Lisa! I volunteer to \n represent Banga!

You're still a drift 
 rat, we can't risk 
 something so 
 important...
Even after all I've done \n for this place? I'm one \n of you now.
Kat...
Great! It looks like \n we've got our \n competition.
Do it...
No...
Well done Fi!
This bet is off! \n There's been foul play.
Foul play!?
Whoa, what are you \n saying, brother of mine?
I refuse to be involved \n in an unfair fight.
It violates the Lhao \n Warrior's Code.
Fi...
That's nonsense! What \n about the bet!?
Let's decide the winner \n with a game of B'oarack.
B'oa...rack?

A Lhao tradition. I'll 
 preside over the event 
 to avoid any more 
 cheating.
Fine, whatever. Just \n let's get it over with!
B'oarack is a ceremony \n for pleasing the gods.

The only people allowed 
 to enter the sacred 
 fighting ground are the 
 competitors.
Kat, you'll have to \n fight without your \n little bodyguard.
If that puts you at a \n disadvantage, we can \n make an exception.
It's only fair after \n what happened in the \n target game.
Well, I don't know much \n about the ceremony...
But if I'm supposed to \n enter alone, that's the \n way it has to be.
Dusty, stay here with \n Cecie and cheer me on.
Meow!

Each competitor has 
 three bells, 
 representing the 
 harvest.

The one who takes all 
 three bells from their 
 competitor is judged 
 worthy by the gods.
If you leave the arena, \n you forfeit your right \n to be judged.
Got it! So just grab \n Fi's bells while \n protecting my own.
This time, may the gods \n decide who is truly \n worthy.
To your places, \n we'll begin.

Noble competitors, may 
 the ringing of your 
 bells reach the ears of 
 the gods.

I knew the Gravity Queen would pull it off!
